reasoning: The critique targets the sub-claim that superintelligent reflection/advice will (by reducing empirical disagreement/transparent errors) drive convergence and improve bargaining. But the essay already substantially downplays this optimism in 2.3.1 (explicitly arguing superintelligence doesn’t imply convergence and that advisor-selection/value-lock-in are likely), so falsifying the optimistic version isn’t very damaging to the essay’s overall conclusions (centrality low). As an objection to any residual optimism, it adds a coherent Goodhart/adversarial-adaptation mechanism and links it to the essay’s own ‘free parameters’/‘epistemic black holes’ points, but it’s largely reinforcing what the essay already says rather than overturning a relied-upon step (strength low-moderate). The mechanism is plausible in broad strokes, though some claims (e.g., ‘stable attractors of self-endorsing reflective loops’ becoming more resistant specifically because superintelligently defended) are speculative and not fully argued (correctness moderate-high). It is concise and understandable (clarity high), stays on one issue (single-issue high), and has little fluff (dead weight low). Overall it’s a decent elaboration, but not a major problem for the position because it is mostly “priced in.”
title: Superintelligent reflection creates Goodhart pressure and self-reinforcing epistemic lock-in
